title: Asynchronously Testing Framework
description:
As an engineer, I want
 # To observe and validate events that come in and out my service.
 # That there will be no dead time (when there is a thread do nothing but sleep) to wait for events which I want to observed.

Framework should provide features
 # I can define what should be done / prepared before my tests.
 # I can define topics of events that I want to observe.
 # When an event coming from a topic that I observed, I can figure out this event is what I "not waiting for" / "is waiting for and the content is also what I expect" / "is waiting for and the content is not what I expect".
 # Other tasks (storing, threading, etc.) should be handled be the framework without my instruction (programming or configuration).
 # When I want to change the default behavior (storing, storage type, messaging, message broker type, sending and receiving REST messages, etc.) I can do it freely without changing my testing code.

More details can be referred in [*Wiki Page*|https://wiki.absolute.com/display/~TLe/Proposal+-+Asynchronously+Testing+Framework].
This wiki page may be little out of date in details, but the core concepts and features are stable.

title: Dashboard snapshots

 * Users can delete Dashboard snapshot which that user created.
 * Users can come back to the live Dashboard.

description:

 # CTSRV will download components from pin folder to the device and executes them
 ## These are special components, not the actual ones
 # When component is executed, it will connect to SQL database to read what should it respond back to CTSRV (to mimic different device type/models)
 # CTSRV will carry on with the call and call is ended, the result is collected at the end.

title: Contract Test for Microservices Component Testing
description:
As the company moving toward fully microservices architecture, component level tests will increase to ensure proper integration. However, with so many API interfaces, how do we keep track of all the agreed contract interface between microservices? Contract Testing. It is not a new technology, but it's definitely new to Absolute.

Contract Testing in short description is to make sure the agreed API interface between provider and consumer does not change. And if changed, the test will know before the code is merged.

Assumption in this hackathon project.
 * Assuming the component testing is there and working during Pull Request build time.

What we want to hack about
 * We want to receive consumer microservice's call to the provider and provide a mocked response that the consumer.
 * Then we will take that consumer call, and play it back to the provider to receive a real response from the provider.
 * By comparing the mocked response we gave out with the real response we received from the provider, we can determine if the contract is met of not.

title: Evaluate using a different database technology for Web Usage
description:
Collection of Web Usage data has been enabled in Production for a few months now. It is clear that the amount of data being processed, stored, summarized, and reported on, is massive. The document design in mongo, and the processing pipelines have been tweaked and refactored multiple times, to help ensure that reports don't timeout. 

Perhaps the problem would be easier to solve with a different database technology?

# Investigate the performance differences using MySQL and Mongo

# We created the MySQL database onto the team environment. 
# We researched the different configuration settings, and enabled compression.
# With needed large chunks of data for testing against so we experimented with various ways to export the data out of Mongo to insert into MySQL. We transferred over 4 million+ files. We had to kill the export as we were running out of disk space.
# We changed the configuration of MySQL to point to a different partition within the team environment which contained 4T of space. After working through the various issues related to re-configuring the initial set up, tables, we attempted to re-import the data.
# Once exported we then imported the data from a .csv file into MySQL. This process took many hours. 
# We created the following tables named SiteDailyRollup, SiteDailyTotals and SiteDailyHistory. 

Some of the pitfalls we ran into are
* The amount of time to transfer the data took many hours. Resources were limited.
* We had to baby sit and kill off services which were killing memory and disk usage which was needed to complete the transfer. We were using most of the allocated memory and were pushing into disk.
* The TTL on the data-set we were attempting to use was cleared out on the second day. We had to use backup data to re-import it back into Mongo.
* Data Types for Date were re-imported as Strings and needed to be converted back into the correct data type. 
* We had to rebuild the database multiple times due to space limitations and corrupted data.

{code:java}
SELECT r.tpd, SUM(CASE WHEN t.dow IN (1,2,3,4,5) AND t.hr IN (9,10,11,12,13,14) THEN t.total END) inSchool, SUM(CASE WHEN (t.dow IN (1,2,3,4,5) AND t.hr NOT IN (9,10,11,12,13,14) OR t.dow IN (0,6)) THEN t.total END) outSchool FROM SiteDailyRollup r JOIN SiteDailyTotals t ON t.sid=r.id AND t.ld=r.ld AND t.tpd=r.tpd WHERE r.accountUid = 'fd20bd7e-2e6f-4e88-b60f-2435a6753f1a' GROUP BY r.tpd;
{code}

To Create the SiteDailyRollup Table and Index, these are the commands we used (separated as we created them at different times):

{code:java}
CREATE TABLE SiteDailyRollup (id BINARY(255) PRIMARY KEY, accountUid BINARY(36) NOT NULL, ld DATE NOT NULL, dow INT NOT NULL, tpd VARCHAR(256) NOT NULL, ttlDt DATETIME ) ENGINE=InnoDB KEY_BLOCK_SIZE=8;

{code}

{code}

{code}

title: Device and network performance issue identification
description:
What if Absolute could provide a report or graph showing a customer which machines are performing poorly, and identify when & what network the devices were on when poor performance was noticed?

With web usage monitoring, we have a very convenient point at which to observe network and application performance. We can determine how long pages take to load and render, and we can time network requests. With this data, we can analyze the data to determine normal performance for a device or group of devices, and find outliers. We can also determine whether the device was on the corporate network or some other network. (We can focus the analysis on google.com pages, since Google has highly optimized their infrastructure – any performance issues are more likely to be in the network near the user, or in the device itself.)

With this information, our hypothetical IT/network manager can identify times or devices that are performing poorly, and use that to determine whether network problems or device issues are occurring consistently, and remediate the issues.

Tasks for page load performance monitoring:

* In web usage core, extend the webNavigation interface to record navigation event start & completion times, and (if possible) byte counts or page size, and report elapsed time and other data in page load event data
* In web monitor inbound processor, parse & keep the page load elapsed time & other data in the DetailedActivity
* Run the modified web usage core code in Windows and/or Chromebooks in different locations & networks to collect data (perhaps intentionally slow the device or network traffic to illustrate issues)
* Investigate and implement algorithm(s) to analyze and display the data

Possible further work (depending on time):

* Use the browser's webRequest onBeforeRequest / onCompleted events to determine detailed network traffic performance; build a map indexed by server name & timestamp recording the latest byte count & elapsed time
      * When reporting a page load event, report the latest webRequest elapsed time & byte count
      * In web monitor inbound processor, parse & keep the network performance data
      * Run the modified web usage core code in different locations & networks to collect data
      * Implement clustering algorithm(s) and display results

title: Smart Firmware Lock
description:
Absolute Persistence can be easily blocked by a savvy user, so a stolen device, for example, will never call home. Also, a stolen device with Absolute Persistence is fully usable with a non-Windows OS (e.g. Linux). The current Firmware Lock feature allows for the device to be locked remotely, if done in the right time while device is online. But if the device is hacked while offline, Persistence can still be disabled and our lock feature won't work.

This hackathon idea is to prototype a solution based on the patent application ABS094 implementing an advanced/smart lock that would automatically engage upon detection of a hacking attempt.

title: Device report permission on fields
description:
*Protect device report data by applying permission on the fields that will be returned to the customer*

More details

Existing permission in Absolute:
 * {*}Permission on API{*}, by URP: a user is able to call an certain API if he/she have the corresponding permission
 * {*}Permission on devices{*}, by device-group: a user is able only to see devices of the group that he/she is assigned to

DeviceReport is the central place to gather all information of the devices from many feature: device-freeze, stolen, cdf, geo, software status... Until now, all users have permission to access device-report API to get devices, with all fields of features. For example, user who do not have cdf permission but can see the cdf fields of the returned devices.

To fulfil the permission picture, we introduced a new *Permission on fields* feature (see picture below).

There is a default mapping from permissions to  java-field-names. Customers are able to edit this mapping, here is why:
 * Suppose we apply this change on Production. And one day a user open a report and can not see the fields he/she wants as before. He/she is not fine with that. What should we do? We can not ask the admin to add more permission for this specific user, or rollback this change. So there should be the place to config to solve this problem for a specific customer.
 * Base on the customer's business, they can have specific config to what they want. A user can see all the device-freeze information, but not the passcode, or can see all cdf , but not a specific cdf (that contains sensitive information)

title: Performance issues: Early detection
description:
We want to prevent the performance issue before it happens on production. But it can be potential somewhere among a bunch of places in the system. Where should we start?

h3. *Problems*

* A type of requests can impact to other requests and make the entire system slow down
* Dev and QA environment do not have the way to evaluate the health of the _system._ Current performance test only focus on a specific service.

h3. *The goal is to answer the two questions*

* What are the most potentially problematic places that need to pay attention first?
* How to evaluate the heath of the _system_ before applying the changes on production?

h3. *The proposal*

*Simulate the real traffic of production on a subsystem*

* By using [https://k6.io/.|https://k6.io/] Scope for now: A subsystem that includes related services, base on the same mongo cluster.

*Find the most problematic places*

* Create a new option "explain=true" for the API that use odata, to instead of returning records, it will return the corresponding mongo query and execution plan. To quickly find the suspicious odata requests.
* For each suspicious requests/messages/scheduler, evaluate how it impact to the subsystem (by latency increment, errors, RAM, CPU...)
* Compare the results

*Evaluate the the changes of system before applying on production*

* Define acceptant criteria, SLAs to evaluate how efficiency of the changes
* Practically prove the solution before applying on production (Example: Is it better to move a suspicious services out of RSC cluster, like DeviceReport before?)

More details is at [https://myabsolute.atlassian.net/wiki/display/~NDo/Performance+issues%3A+Early+detection|https://myabsolute.atlassian.net/wiki/display/~NDo/Performance+issues%3A+Early+detection]
